metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Booleans
A JavaScript Boolean represents one of two values: true or false .
content.html: A JavaScript Boolean represents one of two values: true or false.

content.text: Boolean Values
Very often, in programming, you will need a data type that can only have one of two values, like
content.html: Very often, in programming, you will need a data type that can only have one of two values, like

content.text: For this, JavaScript has a Boolean data type. It can only take the values true or false .
content.html: For this, JavaScript has a Boolean data type. It can only take the values true or false.

content.text: The Boolean() Function
You can use the Boolean() function to find out if an expression (or a variable) is true:
content.html: You can use the Boolean() function to find out if an expression (or a variable) is true:

content.code_html: Boolean(10 > 9)

content.text: Or even easier:
content.html: Or even easier:

content.code_html:
(10 > 9)
10 > 9

content.text: Comparisons and Conditions
The chapter JS Comparisons gives a full overview of comparison operators.
content.html: The chapter JS Comparisons gives a full overview of comparison operators.

content.text: The chapter JS If Else gives a full overview of conditional statements.
content.html: The chapter JS If Else gives a full overview of conditional statements.

content.text: Here are some examples:
content.html: Here are some examples:

content.code_html:
Operator Description Example
== equal to if (day == "Monday")
> greater than if (salary > 9000)
< less than if (age < 18)

content.text: The Boolean value of an expression is the basis for all JavaScript comparisons and conditions.
content.html: The Boolean value of an expression is the basis for all JavaScript comparisons and conditions.

content.text: Everything With a "Value" is True

content.code_html:
100

3.14

-15

"Hello"

"false"

7 + 1 + 3.14

content.text: Everything Without a "Value" is False

content.code_html:
let x = 0;
Boolean(x);

let x = -0;
Boolean(x);

let x = "";
Boolean(x);

let x;
Boolean(x);

let x = null;
Boolean(x);

let x = false;
Boolean(x);

let x = 10 / "Hallo";
Boolean(x);

content.text: JavaScript Booleans as Objects
Normally JavaScript booleans are primitive values created from literals:
content.html: Normally JavaScript booleans are primitive values created from literals:

content.code_html: let x = false;

content.text: But booleans can also be defined as objects with the keyword new :
content.html: But booleans can also be defined as objects with the keyword new:

content.code_html: let y = new Boolean(false);

let x = false;
let y = new Boolean(false);

// typeof x returns boolean
 // typeof y returns object

content.text: Do not create Boolean objects.
content.html: Do not create Boolean objects.

content.text: The new keyword complicates the code and slows down execution speed.
content.html: The new keyword complicates the code and slows down execution speed.

content.text: Boolean objects can produce unexpected results:
content.html: Boolean objects can produce unexpected results:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = false;
let y = new Boolean(false);

let x = false;
let y = new Boolean(false);

content.text: Note the difference between (x==y) and (x===y).
content.html: Note the difference between (x==y) and (x===y).

content.text: Comparing two JavaScript objects always return false .
content.html: Comparing two JavaScript objects always return false.

content.text: Complete Boolean Reference
For a complete reference, go to our Complete JavaScript Boolean Reference .
content.html: For a complete reference, go to our Complete JavaScript Boolean Reference.

content.text: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Boolean properties and methods.
content.html: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Boolean properties and methods.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: let x = 5 < 2; What will be the value of x ?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
let x = 5 < 2;
What will be the value of x?
